result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Donald Wayne Sexton

records.addlTxt: Status conference on December 12, 2022 at 10:30 am. - Notice not mailed to defendant as he does not live at that address. Need an updated address.

9:33 AM Defendant Donald Wayne Sexton appeared by video.  Attorney Richard S Gondik Jr appeared by video for Donald Wayne Sexton.  Attorney Mark Adam Fruehauf appeared by video for State of Wisconsin. 
Court reviews appearances, notes family member of victim also appears. 
Court questions the status of case.
State indicates still in discussions, request another STC.
Attorney Gondik agrees.
Motion to admit statements to sit in abeyance until trial.
Attorney Gondik makes argument in support of motion for modification of bond condition. Requesting the no contact be modified to no violent or abusive contact.  Victim's mother appearing in court to support the motion for modification.  Has video contact with victim, states victim also wishes to have in person contact. Has been compliant with his bond for 6 months.
State oppose motion for modification.  Attorney is correct in stating the position of both victim and victim's mother. Basis of objection is the nature of the offense, a course of conduct over a period of time. Makes argument against modification, does not believe it is safe for the victim.
Court questions if the state has considered a GAL be appointed for the child; State has not until today.
Attorney suggests no unsupervised conduct.
Defendant suggests the sister or father of the victims mother.
Victim's mother agrees with supervised contact.  Suggests her sister.
Court modifies bond condition to Third party supervised contact with victim. 
Set stc out 60 days.
State/Attorney Gondik to confer and submit letter in re: naming the third party contact agreed upon so the clerk can prepare a bond.
Status conference scheduled for December 12, 2022 at 10:30 am.
Defendant's Notice of Motion and Motion to Amend Bond Condition
Defendant's Objection to State's Motion to Admit Statements of the Defendant
EX 1 (Sexton)
State's motion for other acts and to admit statements of the defendant
Status conference on September 26, 2022 at 09:30 am.

11:44 AM Defendant Donald Wayne Sexton appeared by video.  Attorney Richard S Gondik Jr appeared by video for Donald Wayne Sexton.  Attorney Mark Adam Fruehauf appeared by video for State of Wisconsin. Court calls case. Attorney acknowledges information, waives reading, enters not guilty plea. Court accepts plea.  Parties ask for status.
Status conference scheduled for September 26, 2022 at 09:30 am.
Arraignment on July 20, 2022 at 11:45 am.

3:46 PM Defendant Donald Wayne Sexton appeared by video.  Attorney Mark Adam Fruehauf appeared by video for State of Wisconsin.  Attorney Garrett M. Gondik appeared by video for Donald Wayne Sexton. 
Court notes motion to reconsider
Att Gondik- no resolution
State agrees
Att Gondik- Court had ruled the motion to dismiss was waived as untimely filed, was filed prior to prelim, requests motions not be ruled denied.
Court notes motion doesn't have to be heard before prelim, just filed.
Att Gondik- Local practice has been to hear motion before prelim. Believes complaint was defective, Information should be amended to clarify which statute client is being charged under.
State requests motions be denied as untimely, filed brief stating position
Court- doesn't understand issue. If motions filed just before prelim they couldn't be heard but they can be heard after prelim.
State points out focus is on charging language. If entire complaint is read it's clear all incidents charged were intentional, not neglectful .
Court- easiest solution is to amend information to state "intentionally"
State agrees
Att Gondik responds- charging documentr should state intent.
Court finds motions were not waived, but no effect on prelim. State can charge as many counts as they like on the information, they just have to show probable cause for one at prelim. Grants motion to reconsider. 
Att Gondik requests charges be clarified
Court notes charging a count under intent doesn't preclude charging another under neglect or recklessness
State requests arraignment be adjourned, will clean up information to show intent as basis for charges.
Court sets new date
Arraignment scheduled for July 20, 2022 at 11:45 am.

records.descr: Demand for Discovery and Inspection - Prosecutor

records.addlTxt:
9:13 AM Defendant Donald Wayne Sexton in court.  Attorney Richard S Gondik Jr in court for Donald Wayne Sexton.  Attorney Angela Wilson in court for State of Wisconsin. Court calls case. Attorney Gondik filed 3 motions this morning, at 9:28. Court indicates motions are waived. Not timely filed. Gondik indicates complaint is defective, soonest they could file these motions. State has not even read the motions yet. Ready to proceed today with evidence. Not prepared to deal with motions today. Fine with adjourning prelims if court needs. Court indicates court can't adequately hear motions with such short notice and finds them waived. Will proceed with preliminary hearings today. 
Court calls case. State calls witness, Christopher Moe, Detective Superior Police Department, S/T. State-direct examination of witness. March 11, 2022, City of Superior, Douglas County, Wisconsin. Objection, best evidence, sustained. Continued questioning. Objection again, overruled. Witness identifies Defendant. Court notes identification of witness. Objection, foundation, sustained. Continued questioning.  Objection, non responsive. Question rephrased. Objection, leading, overruled. No additional questions. Attorney cross examines witness. Objection, relevance, sustained. No further questions. State redirects. Court questions relevance. Question withdrawn. Attorney Gondik questions, Objection, relevance, overruled.
State rests.
State makes argument for bind over. Attorney makes argument in opposition. Court finds probable cause and binds the Defendant over for Arraignment. Court will obtained arraignment dates from Judge Anderson and send out notice. 
Gondik asks for amendment of bond conditions regarding contact with child. State does not oppose. Bond conditions amended to no in person contact with Victim. 
Court reminds the Defendant of their bail conditions. Defendant orally confirms they have received date and time of hearing and confirms they will attend. Defendant provided notice.
Defendant's Notice of Motion and Motion to Dismiss-Defective Complaint
Defendant's Notice of Motion and Motion for Bill of Particulars
Defendant's Notice of Motion and Motion to Make Definite and Certain

3:08 PM Defendant Donald Wayne Sexton appeared by video, in custody with Attorney Jacob Gondik via special appearance. Attorney Angela Wilson in court for State of Wisconsin. Court calls case. Address verified as 15 Hughitt Avenue, Superior, WI. Gondik acknowledges receipt, waives reading, asks for preliminary hearing.  State requests $1000 cash, no contact with Victim 1 or residence, except one time for property retrieval. Cites prior case in March with same victim. This case is based on additional incidents that occured prior to previous case.  Court questions date of offense. State indicates typo  that they will need to correct. these charges occurred prior to March 10th. 
Gondik cites resident of douglas county for many years, has wife and kids here. Asks for higher signature bond. Defendant indicates he can post up to $1,000
Court orders $1000 cash, 10,000 signature bond, with conditions of no contact with Victim or their residence.
Preliminary hearing scheduled for April 6, 2022 at 10:00 am.
